Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2020
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2020, Research Using Biological Collections. The fellowship supports research and training of the Fellow that will utilize biological collections in innovative ways. Effective oceanic resource management requires knowledge of how resources respond to the environment. However, the basic structures of food webs supporting oceanic resources remain poorly understood. In the case of large predators, we often know what they eat but not how they choose what to eat, or which other predators they compete with for food. To understand how large predators like tuna and billfish choose their food, this project will examine prey traits such as body shape and behavior. By doing so, this research will condense diverse diets into general rules used by predators to select prey. Comparing these rules among predators will produce insights into the structure of oceanic food webs. Identifying predators that compete for similar prey types will help us understand how changes in the distributions of predators and prey will impact oceanic food web structure. The Fellow will promote diverse participation in science by (1) working with the Equity, Diversity, and Inclusion Team at Scripps Institution of Oceanography (SIO) to establish a journal club that examines bias and discrimination in scientific disciplines, and (2) creating public curricula on oceanic ecology.

This project will bridge predator feeding habits data at NOAA Southwest Fisheries Science Center and physical prey specimens housed at SIO to facilitate a meta-analysis of oceanic food web structure in the Southern California Current Ecosystem (SCCE). The Fellow will (1) develop a trait-based analysis framework to describe the rules used by predators to select prey, and (2) quantify trait-based resource partitioning among tunas and billfishes in the SCCE. The robustness of this trait framework will be tested by quantifying variability in prey selection rules for predator feeding habits studied both in the SCCE (eutrophic upwelling system) and the central North Pacific (oligotrophic gyre system). The Fellow will receive advanced analytical training in the application of trait-based food web models as well as training in the mentorship of undergraduate and graduate students. To engage diverse communities in STEM education and research, the Fellow will develop an outreach program in collaboration with NOAA, SIO, and the San Diego County Office of Education that uses fish stomach dissections to introduce students to biological oceanography, data analysis, and human impacts on the ocean.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Performance_Institution.Name: Scripps Institution of Oceanography, UC San Diego

POR.DRECONTENT:
As the ocean continues to warm, changes in the abundance and distribution of pelagic (open ocean) species will alter the food available to predators as well as competition among predators. However, our ability to assess how changes in predator-prey overlap will affect pelagic food webs is hindered by a limited understanding of how predators share a common food resource. Current approaches emphasize the results of feeding interactions (e.g., diet composition) rather than their drivers. Describing the drivers of feeding interactions from a traits perspective (e.g., feeding depths/times, prey size, energetic value) will improve our understanding of how food resources are shared among pelagic predators as well as our ability to predict changes to pelagic food webs and services.

This project provided training to Dr. Portner as well as eight students using collections of predator diet data and an exceptional diversity of prey from the California Current Ecosystem (CCE). The team measured biological traits (e.g., length, mass, caloric content) of numerous prey species, and published a database of similar data compiled from the literature for common prey species from the CCE (>250 species). This Pelagic Traits Database is now a public resource that will facilitate future trait-based work. We applied a trait-based approach to examine a time series of albacore tuna diet (Thunnus alalunga) across three oceanographically distinct regions of the CCE. Although albacroe diets varied across regions over time, the traits of the dominant prey taxa remained consistent across all regions during our 10+ year time series. Albacore consistently consumed prey with high caloric value that school in shallow waters. 

Dr. Portner applied this trait-based approach to examine taxonomic and vertical resource partitioning among three midwater predators from the central North Pacific Ocean: Hammerjaw (Omosudis lowii), fangtooth (Anoplogaster cornuta), and longnose lancetfish (Alepisaurus ferox). Based on the taxonomic identity and size of prey, we observed ontogenetic variability in diet composition, vertical habitat use, and resource partitioning among these three competitors. Increased overlap in diet and habitat with body size was correlated with increased consumption of all three competitors by the longnose lancetfish. Our findings suggest that the traits approach provides insights into the drivers of resource parititioning among predators, especially when predators share prey species.

All project participants received training on how to identifiy pelagic forage species, analytical methods (e.g., calorimetry), statistical analysis, and scientific writing. Over the course of this project, Dr. Portner supervised four graduate students on projects utilizing trait-based approaches to improve our understanding of pelagic ecosystems, resulting in the publication of two manuscripts and two Master's theses. In total, this project supported the publication of eight scientific papers, which were presented to audiences at seven scientific conferences.

To share the ecological context of this project more broadly, Dr. Portner gave annual lectures in four courses at UCSD (SIO 270B – Fisheries Oceanography; SIO 295S – Introduction to Marine Biodiversity and Conservation; SIO 145L – Methods in Biological Oceanography; SIO – 101 California Coastal Oceanography). As part of an ongoing collaboration between the lab of the project advisor at the host institution (Prof. Anela Choy at Scripps Institution of Oceanography) and The Birch Aquarium, Dr. Portner also helped to develop an educational program that introduces high school students to pelagic ecology and anthropogenic impacts on pelagic food webs. The program at Birch Aquarium has already served thousands of high school students, helping to increase scientific and environmental literacy.
